displaytitle: Bottle in the form of a deer

titles.title: Bottle in the form of a deer

texts.textentryhtml: Although Chavín is certainly the most important and best known Early Horizon Andean culture, other coeval groups produced a variety of art, with varying degrees of influence from Chavín.  Tembladera designates one of three closely related styles known almost exclusively through ceramics, all from the far north coast of Perú.  Among the distinguishing features of Tembladera pottery exhibited in this vessel is the long slender spout with its slight flare at the rim.  While some Tembladera pottery evinces Chavín influence, none can be discerned here.  The body of the vessel is modeled in zoomorphic form; it most closely resembles a deer, but may also portray a camelid.  The legs are abstracted into motifs resembling commas.  Similarly, facial features are rendered in simplified, geometrical fashion.

Before 1969, John L. (1926-2016) and Sue (1928-2005) Tishman, New York (P23/P27) [1]; 2007, John and Sue Tishman sold to private collector, New York [2]; 2009, private collection, New York, gift to Princeton University Art Museum.

Notes:
[1] The Tishmans assigned numbers to works in their collection, whereby lower-numbered objects were acquired prior to higher-numbered objects. The numbers changed over time as works were donated or sold from the collection. A series of appraisals of the collection produced by Robert Sonin, copies of which are in the curatorial file and date as early as 1970, list this object as P23 and P27. Another work on the list, numbered P31 and P35 in different versions, was exhibited and published in 1969, providing a terminus ante quem by which the proposed object was in the Tishman collection.
[2] As per letter from John L Tishman to private collection. Copy in curatorial file.
